We are huge Big Bang Theory fans, having watched most of the seasons 2 if not 3 times.  But I feel this show is starting to wane in humor and grow in annoying personalities.  Way back in season 1, Penny was a kind-hearted, innocent character that brought a softness and warmth to the silliness and social ineptitude of the nerd guys.  Most of the jokes and story elements revolved around nerdy activities, from LAN parties to scientific experiments.  This was the heart of the show and why it was so appealing in a time when most TV shows are either crime drama or reality shows.  More female characters were slowly introduced, and for the most part they have added to the show.  Yet for some reason the writers are making each of the characters more whiny, self-entitled, and mean-spirited with time.  The most glaring example is season 8 Penny.  Instead of kind and a little bumbling in an endearing way, she cuts her hair short, shows zero affection or chemistry toward Leonard, and basically becomes a mean, self-centered, ungrateful rich person that somehow forgot she ate the guys' food for free for 7 years.  Bernadette has also become a snippy little creature, for whom the main gag is how cruel and scary she can be.  Amy has slowly morphed from a shy, socially obtuse nerd girl to being really gross in her numerous sexual comments, particularly to Penny.  And I can't fathom the appeal of Raj's new flame.  It seems they just don't know what to do with his character.

All I can say is, I don't like what they have done with the show and the characters.  They need to get back to their roots of geeky humor and situations, and bring a sweetness back to the female characters.  Otherwise we just have yet another sitcom with no distinct flavor.

He's baaack! Sheldon is retrieved from his soul-searching cross-country train trip (older but no wiser) and that means The Big Bang Theory gang's all here to spread another year's cheer as TV's most attended laugh seminar. Enroll in this comic curriculum to explore Leonard's minor surgery becoming a major catastrophe for his roommate, Howard's obsession over his mom's relationship with retailer-turned-caretaker Stuart, and the peculiar results of Penny's technique as a pharmaceutical sales rep. Discover ways to recreate proms not attended or holiday celebrations not especially beloved and play a new game based on Raj's female attachments. Savor online fan fiction by Amy, watch Bernadette take indelicate command of some delicate family matters and who knows, you might even spot a cool Special Guest or two. Be smart  though never as smart as Sheldon  and enjoy all 24-Episodes of the Complete Season Eight of The Big Bang Theory - a Theory worth its weight in fun every time!

To begin - I have watched this show since day one. I have absorbed everything that the crew has to offer and I have grown with the characters on the show. This season, although decent, felt like the characters weren't themselves. Leonard seems to be getting weaker as a character, even though I felt like overall he was the most interesting. THey make it seem like he simply bows to Penny's every wim.. while also bowing to Sheldon's every wim.. it's like he has become the "b----" character of the group instead of the interesting one. Raj is a helpless horndog, Howard has become whiny at every turn and overly jealous of Stewart to the point of being excessive, and Sheldon seems confused on what direction they want to take his character.

I still enjoyed the season, but I would like to see the characters return to form and progress in a more natural path instead of just randomly jumping around.

Season 8s finale is one of the best episodes yet and entirely whets your appetite to season 9 and whats on point with the finale is that by-and-large a lot of the plot actually carries through toward building to the finale.  Amy is becoming more and more of Americas sweetheart as she continues to put up with Sheldons nonsenseer, difficulties and eccentricities.  The break in their relationship doesnt come so much as a shock as does the reveal of what Sheldon was contemplating.  And then there is Raj and Emily.  Emily is adorable/ creepy, and she doesnt really fit, but can Raj get rid of her?  The heart of the season, though, is found in the relationship and trials of Howard and Bernadette.  These two are comic gold and always play superbly off of each other and when you throw glum chum Stuart into the mix, he whos just happy to be there, it creates a fresh dynamic that is fun but allows some serious tension to underlie the increasingly complicated relationship.  Of course, Howards mom passes this season, and the shows writers and performers honor her memory in a funny way that is completely respectful and will bring tears to fans eyes.  The weak point of the season really is the old hash of Penny and Leonards relationship which loses some luster this season.  Their relationship starts to feel a little doughy.  But overall the laughs are still there and these are characters that we (mostly) come to care about.  Im rooting for Stuart.  I hope he gets his own show (but I wouldnt watch it).  4.5 stars.

If you like mathematical humor, social awkwardness, and random facts about trains or flags, then The Big Bang Theory is the show for you! It is a comedy show that airs on CBS but you can also catch reruns on TBS or FOX. This show offers comedic relief in the form of everyday life.
 The eighth season follows the lives of seven friends, living in California, as they go through the trials and tribulations of life, work, and love. Penny is looking for a new job and trying to navigate her elevated relationship with Leonard. Meanwhile, Amy and Sheldon are working on taking their relationship to the next level while Sheldon is re-evaluating his career change. Raj has a new girlfriend and is now trying to balance both her and the rest of his friends. Bernadette and Howard are working their way through the marital bliss while keeping their careers alive.
 This season has 24 episodes, spaced between 3 discs, which flow smoothly from one to the next. Every episode will make you laugh at least once and they all continue building on the series as a whole. This season will also make you cry multiple times because of how attached you get to the characters and their relationships.
 I bought this season because I started watching The Big Bang Theory when it first aired eight years ago and I got hooked. I got attached to the characters and became addicted to watching it. Getting attached to the characters is easy because every character has some trait that you can also see in yourself. For me, it was the social awkwardness of Sheldon mixed with the brain of Amy and the sarcastic nature of Leonard. This season is ideal for those who just want to go home after school or work, sit back, relax, and laugh because all discs have a play all option. You wouldnt have to move for hours, unless you chose to do so.
 If this sounds like a show that interests you, Friends is another, similar show, which you might appreciate. If this does not sound interesting to you, then there are many other shows that might interest you like Criminal Minds or Bar Rescue.

+++Warning+++  The review contains spoilers from prior seasons and hints, but no major giveaways, from season 8.  If you have not seen the previous season proceed with caution.

The show seems to be one that people either really love or really hate.  Luckily it has been around long enough that most people know where they fall.  It continues to focus on the relationships between the main characters, then tells various ancillary stories of the week while working in some larger ongoing themes.  This season the big stories are Leonard and Penny's ongoing engagement and not setting a date for the wedding, Leonard and Sheldon co-authoring a physics paper which gets them some notoriety, and Sheldon and Amy's relationship.  There are other stories about Stuart mooching off Howard's mom following the destruction of the comic book store last season, Raj's parents  and his new relationship that develops now that he can actually talk to girls without being drunk.  A couple of the stand out episodes of the season are the Billy Bob Thornton guest appearance, Sheldon and Leonard's mothers meeting, and the season finale which ends on a pretty big Sheldon/Amy cliffhanger.  There is also a story line that occurs about 2/3 of the way into the season that leads to some great Howard and Bernadette scenes, and shows off the acting chops of Simon Helberg in general.

For those who get the actual discs, if you get the blu ray, the transfer seems very good, and the show looks and sounds great.  For extras, on disc one there is a relatively short writers panel (and Wil Wheton appearance) from comic-con, and a behind the scenes feature on Billy Bob Thornton's guest appearance.  The second disc has a feature on a group of contest winners who were taken to the set and sit in the studio audience, a short feature on Kaley Cuoco, Jim Parsons and Chuck Lorre getting stars on the Walk of Fame, a tribute to Carol Ann Susi, and a gag reel.  Definitely good for what is there.

If you have loved the show and do not think it has gone stale then you will love this season.  If you have hated the show either because of the laugh track or any other reason, this season is not really going to do anything to change your mind.  Thankfully the show is popular enough that the studio is still released on blu ray, for those of us who get the discs and prefer that format.  The show definitely lays the groundwork for where it is going next season.  As other reviewers have said it would be good if the show took some of the focus off the relationship of the main characters and incorporated more of their families into some episodes.  That said however, if you love the show this is definitely worth adding to your collection.

At some point, all shows go through a slump.  Its almost impossible to keep the quality of the laughs up year and year no matter how great the team is behind the show.  Honestly, Im still waiting for that to happen with The Big Bang Theory.  Here we are at season 8, and Im still loving it.

For those who have missed the show, it centers on a bunch of physicist.  Leading the pack are roommates Leonard (Johnny Galecki) and Sheldon (Jim Parons) who are friends with Raj (Kunal Nayyar) and Howard (Simon Helberg), Howard being the only engineer of the core group.  The series started when Penny (Kaley Cuoco-Sweeting) moved in across the hall from Leonard and Sheldon.  Things have changed, and now Leonard and Penny are engaged, although they still have the same living arrangements.  Over the years, Howard has married Bernadette (Melissa Rauch) and Sheldon has started dating Amy (Mayim Bailik).  Even Raj has a steady girlfriend this year in the form of recurring character Emily (Laura Spencer).

At the end of season seven, Sheldons reaction to changes in his life lead him to leave town on a cross country train trip.  As the season opens, he calls requesting to be picked up.  Why?  Hes been robbed.  That brings him back to the characters home base of Pasadena, California, but he has to start processing the changes in his life.  One of those changes finds him teaching a class at CalTech for the first time.  The catch?  His only student is Howard.  Howard, meanwhile, has to find a way to throw out the first pitch at a baseball game.  Penny leaves behind her dream of acting for a job working pharmaceutical sales at the same company where Bernadette works, although the door might not quite be closed on acting.  Raj has to deal with the fall out of his parents divorce.  The ladies spend an evening uncovering each others shameful secrets.  And the entire gang puts on a prom on their roof with hilarious results.  And we got more of Stuart (Kevin Sussman), the owner of the local comic book store, who was living with Howards mother while his store was rebuilt, much to Howards dismay.

The season took a bit of a somber note when actress Carol Ann Susi died in November.  While never seen, she had provided the off screen voice of Howards mother since the start of the show.  As a result, the writers killed off her character mid-season, providing some well done more somber moments.  It also provided some great storylines late in the season as Howard and Bernadette started working on moving into her home.  I especially loved a ping pong battle episode.

The shows detractors complain that, while it started out as a love letter to geeks, it has now evolved into a show about the characters and their relationships with their significant others.  They do have a valid point.  If you go back and watch the early episodes, the subject matter is often different.

But heres the thing  I don't care.  And why not?  Because Im still laughing.  The jokes are just as funny.  Even if I see them coming, I still cant help but laugh as the characters deliver the lines.

And heres another reason it is a good thing.  Humans grow and change.  The best characters, the ones I love the most, grow and change as well.  If the show tried to stay to the same with the same characters and relationships they had in the first few years, I would be bored with it by now.  Instead, its a show I look forward to watching every Thursday night and the only show I have my DVR record the reruns for.  Thats right, I laugh just as hard at the reruns as I do the first airings of the show, and I never miss a chance to watch the reruns.

Despite the changes, there are still plenty of jokes at geek culture and geeky things.  After all, they built an entire episode around Leonard and Sheldon trying to visit Skywalker Ranch.  The ladies know more than they are willing to admit about the things their men love.  Its a fun show with a fun dynamic.

And the acting continues to be great.  All the main actors know their characters by this point, and their portrayals are perfect.  The recurring characters are fantastic as well and Laura Spencers Emily fits right in as well.  Honestly, I wish wed see more of her.

This season consisted of 24 episodes, which are all included here in their wide screen and full surround.  Extras include a salute to the fans, highlights from the 2014 ComicCon panel, a tribute to Carol Ann Susi, and a gag reel.

So if you need to laugh, I highly recommend The Big Bang Theorys eighth season.  These episodes will fly by all too quickly, and youll be left wanting to know what happens to everyones favorite geeks next.

Right off the bat, I want to say that BBT is one of the best comedy series of all time.  Its merits are so golden I'm even happy to "get through" season 8's sudden fall from comedic grace with optimistic anticipation of season 9!

What went right: Season 1-7

What went wrong: Season 8 (details below)

1. From the very first episode, there was an extraordinarily powerful "aura" of discomfort between the previously "close/warm" familiarity of the characters.  I remember being uncomfortably aware of it and considering the fact that I'm not a director or "professional movie staff" of any kind, it hit me rather hard that everybody on the show seemed like strangers all of a sudden just in the "energy" between them.

2. Penny's hair (and personality) appear to have been cut from the show.  Now, I don't know how much getting an eight dollar snip affects anybody else's personality, but it sure as 7734 upside down affected Penny's!  Not only does the "Miley Cyrus Do" make her LOOK gawky and lanky, it also seems to have made her project that with body language and dialogue delivery.  What I don't know is whether or not that is a deliberate character change intended or just the result of a fashion choice.

3. Finally, when I tune in to watch a comedy on television, I am looking to escape the drama and pains of real life and just have fun, thus my selection of a "comedy" on the tube.  And while I DO understand that a "wee bit o' drama" (nothing too heavy!) to initiate and instigate growing affection for characters is likely to make a better comedy than without, I resent heavy hits of real drama and depressive material.  It's like cheating.  If I WANTED to watch a drama, I'd be tuned into one.  HEAVY drama, in my opinion, is a betrayal of trust against the viewers on the part of the writers and anybody else involved in script production.  --I do realize there will probably be a bunch of "hate replies" to this last statement I've made indicating my apparent lack of humanity and heart because I resent heavy sadness, disease or any other awful life plight in my 22 minute comedy shows, but I have to represent at least a couple of watchers out there in TV land.

Like I said, I'll keep watching because I feel enough loyalty to the characters to stick with them while the going is rough but I sure would love to see the comedy come back.

Another viewer mentioned the under-utilization of Amy and Bernadette--hear hear!  Amy is my favorite character hands down, particularly when she's irritated with/then forgiving poor Sheldon!

A toast!  To another 8 years of BBT!

I've been following the Big Bang Theory since the first season and to my surprise it hasn't lost it's essence and magic after 7 seasons of clever writing, lovely relatable characters and funny jokes. Unlike many other TV series, you don't need to commit to this show in order to enjoy it. With short episodes, having usually independent storylines, you can always watch an episode, or even a scene, whenever you get some free time and want to have some pure fun. Nonetheless, this is one of the best series for binge-watching on weekends or vacation days.

However, you might ask yourself why you need to buy the Blu-rays or DVDs after watching the show on TV or DVR? Other than the joy of collecting such an amazing show, an important thing to know is the show's re-watching value. Even today, I can go back and watch an episode from the first season and enjoy the characters I've been following for all these years.

If you're already a fan of the show, you won't regret spending money on this. If you're a new fan, get ready because you're in for a roller coaster of unforgettable joy.

Pay attention:  the show is going downhill because the real world is intruding on the fantasy world.  Early in the show, if you'll remember, there was plenty of touching and kissing and talk about sex between the two actors Johnny Galecki (as Leonard) and Kaley Cuoco (as Penny).  Then it was revealed that in real life these two actors had an affair that they'd kept secret.  Not long after that, Kaley Cuoco got married to another man, changed her name to Kaley Cuoco-Sweeting, and from that time on the fantasy relationship between Leonard and Penny has become very tame, tepid, and hands-off.  Notice how all the touching, kissing, and references to sex are completely watered down?  The writers have created a distance between them physically, possibly at the request of the actors themselves.  Who knows.  Now the show focuses on the other actors' relationships, but there's no tension or emotional upset there.  Raj finally gets a girlfriend whom we almost never see.  Howard and Bernadette have become a comfortably married couple.  Sheldon and Amy are going nowhere, as usual.  Ho-Hum.  Much of the appeal of the show used to be based on the "Will they? or Won't they?" plots, none of which hold any interest any more.  The writers may try to pump up the show's appeal by using the same old story lines:  Leonard and Penny break up for some reason, Howard and Bernadette have a crisis of some kind, Sheldon and Amy go one step farther, Raj and his girlfriend??  Same old, same old.  Time to move on.  I'm done watching.  The show is tired and the writers are uninspired.

Like many, I am a huge fan of this show.  This episode, "The Hook-Up Reverberation" left me with some doubt about the direction of the story line to come.  99% was good old fashion comedy we have all come to love about this group of actors and the lives the lead.  However, this friction between Penny and Emily where they "hate" each other is truly unnecessary and has the potential to sour the love for the show if they continue along this story line.

Every week many of us turn to this show simply for the pure enjoyment.  Some tune in for the nostalgia for our own past and our ability to connect with these characters in one or another.  We want to cheer for these nerds that overcame adversity and are now able to have successful personal lives.  Aren't we all happy that the nerds all have girl friends and are finding happiness?  Can most of us relate to this?  This is one of the factors that has made this show the ultimate success

This is one of those shows we don't want to see a long running conflict between characters.  The audience wants these characters to find there happiness, we cheer for these characters because we can in fact relate to them from some of our personal experiences.  I recognize that conflict makes for good story lines...such as Penny and Sheldon when she had three strikes and was banished from the apartment.  But the conflict was brilliantly resolved within that episode.

A continuation of conflict between Penny and Emily is not what the viewers want.
